The artist's stage name was Liza Minnelli, born on November 12, 1946, in New York City. The daughter of the renowned entertainer Judy Garland and director Vincente Minnelli, she grew up immersed in the world of show business. Her talents were evident from an early age, making her an iconic figure in entertainment.

Liza Minnelli's career began in the late 1960s, with her first major breakthrough coming with her appearances on the variety show "The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson." Known for her captivating voice and magnetic stage presence, she quickly gained popularity and became a household name.

In 1972, Minnelli's career soared with her mesmerizing performance in the film "Cabaret," for which she won an Academy Award for Best Actress. This marked the beginning of a fruitful collaboration with director Bob Fosse, leading to several successful musicals, including "New York, New York" (1977), "Arthur" (1981), and "Garbo Talks" (1984).

Aside from her acting achievements, Minnelli's singing prowess remains unparalleled. She has released multiple successful albums throughout her career, including "Liza with a 'Z' (1972), "To Wish You a Merry Christmas" (1978), and "Liza's Back" (1972).

Minnelli has continued to grace the stages of the world with her performances, often collaborating with her father Vincente on their final collaboration, the Broadway musical "Judy and Me" (2002). She has also contributed to numerous tribute shows, honoring her legendary mother Judy Garland.

Throughout her illustrious career, Liza Minnelli has remained a prominent figure in the entertainment industry, and her incredible talent, style, and charisma have secured her a special place in show business history.
